section.title: Use translation memories
section.para: When a project is initially created, it comes with its own empty project translation memory, the file, located in the folder. This memory is gradually filled as your translation progresses.
Existing translations are used to speed up the translation process.

listitem.para: If a given sentence has already been translated once, there is no need to retranslate it. See the project property.
If an old translation is similar to the contents of the segment you are translating, you can recycle it in your translation. See the pane for details.
You can also make use of reference translation memories by putting them in the folder of your project.

section.title: Create your own TMs
section.para: When you use to create the target documents for a project, OmegaT also outputs three translation memories that reflect the current state of the translation for the files in the source folder. See the project property for details.

Each of the three files constitutes a bilingual export of the current content of your translation. Their content comes from the global project memory () but is strictly limited to what you have translated so far.
You can also use the tool to create a TMX from two files in a format that OmegaT supports.

section.title: Reuse TMs
section.para: To reuse translation memories from a previous project you have 2 options:

listitem.para: Open the old project and put the new source files in its folder.
After reloading the old project, all its translation memory will be applied to the new source files.

note.para: That’s the easiest way to work on the new version of an already translated document.

listitem.para: Put the reference memories that you took from the old project and put them in the folder of the new project. Depending on how reliable the memory is, you can prefer to put it in either of the following subfolder:

note.para: That’s the preferred method if you want to start your translation from scratch.

section.title: Reading TMs from other tools
section.para: OmegaT can read conformant TMX memories produced by other tools.

Some tools produce invalid TMX files under certain conditions. You will have to fix them if you want to use them as reference memories, otherwise OmegaT will report an error and fail to load them. Fixes are generally simple, and the error message provided by OmegaT will help you pinpoint the error. You can also ask the user group for advice if you have problems.

section.title: Managing your TMs
section.para: You may want to store translation memories in separate folders, by client or by specialty so as to be able to reuse them quickly when need arises. Any storage folder can be used in replacement of the project folder. See the section of the project property dialog.

section.title: Creating a TM specific to selected documents
section.para: In situations where you need to share a TMX that contain only the text from certain specific files and excludes other content, follow the procedure below:

listitem.para: Copy the documents for which you want to create a translation memory into the source folder of your project.
Open the project.
Use to find any untranslated segments (and eventually translate them),
Use to check for possible issues,
Use to create the TMX files that correspond to the current contents.

section.para: The TMX files located in the exported translation memory folder now contain only the original and translated text, in the selected language pair, of the files you copied into the source folder. See the project property for details.

section.title: Share TMs
section.para: For large jobs involving a team of translators, it is easier for everyone involved in sharing common translation memories rather than pass local versions back and forth.
There are two ways to share translation memories:

listitem.para: See the section above.
If you write the TMX file to a folder on a shared disk, you can ask your partner to use that folder in replacement of the folder for the current translation.
Conversely, you can ask your partner to write the project TMX files to a folder on a shared disk that you will use in replacement of your folder for the current translation.

OmegaT instantaneously notices modifications to TMX files. Therefore, any time one side creates or modifies such a TMX using , the other side does not need to do anything to have that TMX recognized locally.

This approach also works just as well for sharing glossaries where the project writable glossary (with a non-default name to avoir overwriting) is located in a common glossary folder. See the appendix for details.

note.para: Such sharing works well when the lag between TMX updates is not important, for example, a translator sends data to a reviewer a few times a day.

listitem.para: OmegaT uses collaborative version control systems to share data.
Such systems are free to use, install and manage and are widely used in the computer development world, making them extremely robust.
See the how-to for details.

section.title: Bridge two languages
section.para: OmegaT displays fuzzy matches in the pane. Such matches are by default limited to the source and target languages defined in the dialog, but you can also add matches in languages that are not the target language. See the preference for details.
With OmegaT, you can also display a third language right under the source segment to use as an alternative language reference for the source text.

— ¶ ————————————————————— A whitespace character: [ 	
\x0B ] fr-ZB: Un caractère d'espacement (espace, tabulation, etc.) : [

\x0B ] Un caractère d'espacement : [

example.para: The first line is the original English, the second an old French version with an arbitrary language code, the third the Japanese version with an equally arbitrary language code, and the 4th the current translation to French.

listitem.para: create a folder called tmx2source in the folder,
copy your "first-third" language translation memory there,
rename the memory LL_CC.tmx or LL-CC.tmx, where LL is the internal language code that you want to display as reference and CC is an arbitrary 2-letter code.

note.para: You can use any number of TMX files in as many different language pairs as "bridge" languages as you want.
